query: What is the evidence for actions that can mitigate environmental pollution from salmon farming?
relevant_summary: A trial in Tasmania, Australia, found that the sediment community structure under Atlantic salmon cages became more similar to that of non-impacted sites over two fallowing cycles [1027]. Two controlled studies, from Iceland and Norway, found higher survival rates in vaccinated salmon compared to unvaccinated control groups post-exposure to disease-causing bacteria [733]. Two other controlled studies in Australia and Canada reported higher survival in salmon infected with marine flexibacteriosis and bacterial kidney disease after vaccination [733]. In Scotland, a study recorded lower lice numbers on Atlantic salmon in cages using a fallowing system [1026]. Another study in Australia found no difference in mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease in cages where a fallowing system had been used [1026].

query: Besides fallowing, what other methods can mitigate the impact of salmon farms on the surrounding benthic environment and local species?
relevant_summary: Integrated aquaculture systems can be used to absorb waste from salmon farms, with one study showing greater growth of scallops grown near fish farms (932), another noting that blue mussels absorbed waste from a salmon farm (932), and a third reporting enhanced algal growth adjacent to fish farms (932). However, a study in Spain found no evidence of oysters and mussels feeding on fish farm waste (932). Other mitigation methods include using vaccinations to increase survival rates in salmon exposed to disease-causing bacteria (733), breeding for resistance traits to increase survival from diseases like infectious pancreatic necrosis (735), and using probiotics and immunostimulants to increase survival and reduce lice infection (732). Additionally, altering the cage size, with larger cages showing lower levels of amoebic gill disease (742), and altering lighting, with low-intensity light reducing the number of lice (741), have been shown to be effective. Aerobic training may also increase survival rates in salmon with infectious pancreatic necrosis (740). Finally, freshwater bathing has been explored to reduce amoebic gill disease, though studies show mixed results (739).

query: Beyond chemical treatments, what alternative methods are available to control sea lice on Atlantic salmon farms?
relevant_summary: A controlled study in Ireland found that using corkwing and goldsinny cleaner wrasse was as effective at controlling sea lice infestations as chemical treatments (738). However, another study found that rockcook cleaner wrasse were not effective in preventing lice outbreaks (738). Additionally, a replicated, controlled study in Norway indicated that salmon kept in low-intensity artificial light or natural lighting had fewer lice (741). The same study showed that the intensity of artificial light was directly related to the number of lice found on the fish (741).

query: What are the available strategies for reducing the environmental impact of waste from salmon farms on the surrounding ecosystem?
relevant_summary:
Fallowing may be used to reduce pollution from salmon farms. A trial in Tasmania found sediment community structure under Atlantic salmon cages became more similar to non-impacted sites over two fallowing cycles (1027). In addition, a study in Scotland recorded lower lice numbers on Atlantic salmon in cages using a fallowing system (1026). However, a study in Australia found that a fallowing system made no difference to mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease in cages (1026).

Integrated aquaculture systems have also been studied. One replicated, controlled study in the USA reported greater growth of scallops grown next to fish farms (932). In addition, a study in Canada found that blue mussels absorbed waste from a salmon farm (932). A replicated, controlled study in Scotland also reported enhanced algal growth when placed adjacent to fish farms (932). In contrast, one study in Spain found no evidence that oyster and mussels were feeding on fish farm waste (932).
